title: A 62-year-old male with symptomatic hip osteoarthritis
clinical_history: A 62-year-old male, Mr. Thompson, presents with a 6-month history of progressive right hip pain. He reports that the pain started insidiously, with no specific incident or trauma. Initially, he experienced stiffness and mild pain in the hip and groin area, which has gradually worsened over time. He describes the pain as being worse in the morning and after prolonged periods of inactivity. The pain is now affecting his daily activities, including walking and climbing stairs.
aggrevating_factors: prolonged walking (>30 minutes), climbing stairs, standing for long periods, and activities that involve hip flexion, such as putting on socks
picture: The patient reports a 24-hour pain pattern, with pain increasing throughout the day, peaking in the late afternoon, and easing slightly with rest.
easing_factors: rest, heat application, and over-the-counter pain medications like acetaminophen
past_history: history of a left knee meniscal tear, treated conservatively 10 years ago. He has also had episodes of lower back pain, which have been managed with physical therapy.
medical_history: hypertension, controlled with medication. He has a family history of osteoarthritis.
medications: acetaminophen as needed for pain, lisinopril for hypertension
personal_history: married, with two adult children. He works as an accountant but has had to reduce his work hours due to his symptoms. He enjoys golfing but has had to stop due to his hip pain.
imaging: X-rays of the right hip show joint space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis, consistent with hip osteoarthritis.
